results.title: The 1956 Olympic story [Winter Olympics in Cortina, Italy]
results.creator_credit: Helms Athletic Foundation, Harry Leaman and Norman Mackay
results.brief_description: Documentary film on the Olympic Winter Games in Cortina in the Italian Alps, 1956. Sets the panoramic views of Cortina and the venues where the 1956 Winter games will be held whilst highlighting the previous 1952 Oslo Winter games with footage of specific events. Also includes footage of Melbourne in 1956 featuring the Melbourne Cricket Ground and St Kilda Town Hall and images of the 1952 Summer games in Helsinki. Narrated by Fred Hessler.

results.title: The 1954 Redex trial
results.creator_credit: Litchfield Productions, Roland Litchfield and Peter Whitchurch
results.brief_description: A record of the 1954 Redex around Australia reliability car trial. The 9,600 mile route commenced at Sydney and passed through every Australian capital city. Only 124 of the 248 starters finished the 18-day trial. The film captures the atmosphere and illustrates conditions experienced by drivers in the trial as they drove through the rain, extremes of heat and cold, choking dust, across roads which in many places were rarely used bush tracks full of hazards to both car and their weary, strained drivers, who, at the same time had to be careful of secret controls to check their speed. Concluding sequences show arrival, welcome and presentation of the winner.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Litchfield Productions, Roland Litchfield and Peter Whitchurch

results.title: The 1940's house. Volume 2: episodes 4-5
results.creator_credit: Channel Four Television, Simon Shaw and Caroline Ross Pirie
results.brief_description: Part 2 of the Hymer’s 8 week stay in the 1940’s house. “1944-1945: the beginning of the end”: the first lot of wartime treats from the U.S turns up on the Hymer’s doorstep and is favourably received. D Day arrives and the family is treated to a picnic at the Biggins Air Show. When VE Day is upon them there’s a dance to attend with 1940’s enthusiasts. Kirstie is sent to work on aircraft and the family prepare to leave Braemar Gardens. “2001: Homecoming”: On returning from the 1940’s house, Lyn, Michael, Kirstie and the boys discuss how their lives have changed individually and as a family. We are also privy to bloopers from the show - scenes in which the family contravened the regulations laid down to them during the 8 week period. The War Cabinet provides feedback on how serious/usual their breaches were and how they think the Hymer’s fared in general. Footage of the Hymer’s visiting a refuge shelter at Chiselhurst is also shown.

results.title: The 1940's house. Volume 1. Episodes 1-3
results.creator_credit: Channel Four Television and Simon Shaw
results.brief_description: In January 2000, British families vied to take part in being transported back to life in the 1940’s for an 8 week period, under the watchful eye of a mock War Cabinet and complete with authentic 1940’s correspondence, decor, fashion, air raids and grocers. This is the account of the “winners”, the Hymer family - parents Lyn and Michael, daughter Kirstie and her 2 sons - who moved from their Braemar Gardens home to the 1940’s house in West Wickham. “The Home front” (Dir: Simon Shaw): The Hymer’s move into Braemar Gardens and begin preparing themselves for the next 8 weeks. “1939-1940: Into the unknown” (Dir: Simon Shaw): the children become attached to the family rabbits intended for breeding, Lyn and Kirstie prepare an emergency food kit and learn about the intricacies of attending to their nightly toilette. Everyone pitches together to blackout the windows and construct an Anderson shelter. “1941-1943: Women at war” (Dir: Caroline Ross Pirie): Michael is sent away to work, leaving Lyn and Kirstie, like many women on the home front during the 40’s, left to look after family and home. They are also called upon to join the W.V.S (Women’s Voluntary Services), and find that the absence of Michael and their entry into the work force changes the family dynamics. Ben is assigned as fuel warden. This is a reality show with a difference. It features the usual tenets of direct camera address (minus the 24 hour intrusiveness), frustration at wanting to leave the “game”, plus a final episode in which the participants discuss their experience. There is ultimately no prize, other than the lessons they have learnt from their time in Braemar Gardens. Narrated by Geoffrey Palmer.

results.title: The 13th Warrior = The Thirteenth Warrior
results.creator_credit: Touchstone Pictures, Michael Crichton, Ned Dowd and John McTiernan
results.brief_description: Set in 922 AD, an Arab courtier accompanies a party of Vikings to the barbaric North where he is reluctantly enlisted to help them battle the flesh eating Wendol. Cast includes: Antonios Banderas, Omar Sharif.

results.title: The 12 steps: recovering from addictions. - Steps One to Eight.
results.creator_credit: Manitoba TV, Kaleidoscope Entertainment, Sleeping Giant Productions and Jim Hanley
results.brief_description: Throughout the 13 episodes, 12 characters are constantly entwined. Their experiences of the Alcoholics Anonymous 12 step program, compellingly told and captured first hand are interspersed with expert opinion for structural cohesiveness and direction. Step 1: “We admitted we were powerless over our addiction - that our lives had become unmanageable.” 2. “Came to believe that a Power greater than ourselves could restore us to sanity”. 3. “Made a decision to turn our will and our lives over to the care of God as we understood him.”. 4. “Made a searching and fearless moral inventory of ourselves.” 5. “Admitted to ourselves and to another human being the exact nature of our wrongs.” 6. “Were entirely ready to have God remove all these defects of character.” 7. “Humbly asked him to remove our shortcomings.” 8. “Made a list of all persons we had harmed and became willing to make amends to them all.” Narrated by John Vernon.

results.title: The 12 steps: recovering from addictions. - Steps Nine to Thirteen.
results.creator_credit: Manitoba TV, Kaleidoscope Entertainment, Sleeping Giant Productions and Jim Hanley
results.brief_description: The 12 characters introduced in episodes one to eight continue relating their experiences of the Alcoholics Anonymous 12 step program. Step 9. “Made direct amends to such people wherever possible, except when to do so would injure them or others.” 10. “Continued to take personal inventory and when we were wrong promptly admitted to it.” 11. “Sought through prayer and meditation to improve our conscious contact with God as we understood him, praying only for knowledge of his will and the power to carry that out.” 12. “Having had a spiritual awakening as a result of these steps, we tried to carry this message to addicts, and to practice these principles in all our affairs.” 13. “Relapse.” Narrated by John Vernon.

results.title: The 'Shop steward'
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Guy Glover and Morten Parker
results.brief_description: A dramatized presentation of the role of the shop steward in the effective day-to-day funtioning of free trade unionism. The film beings with the election of machinists Johnny Walachuk as shop steward for the men in his section of a large industrial plant. Continuing, it shows the part the shop steward plays in carrying out the grievance procedures set up by company and union. How Johnny fulfills responsibility to protect from infractions of the agreement the men who elected him, is told in his own words and typifies the function of the union shop stewards generally in Canada.

results.title: Thaumatropes
results.brief_description: A thaumatrope is an optical toy that binds a disc to lengths of string. Illustrated on each side of the disc are distinct images that become one when you pull the string and the thaumatrope spins.

constellations_primary.name: There's always a lighthouse
constellations_primary.description: The thaumatrope was an early optical illusion device popular in the Victorian era and was important to the development of the moving image.

results.description: How do you cage a bird? With a thaumatrope, an optical toy that binds a disc to lengths of string. Illustrated on each side of the disc are distinct images that become one when you pull the string and the thaumatrope spins. The first known thaumatrope was invented by John Ayrton Paris in 1824, when he used it to demonstrate his theory of ‘persistence of vision’ to London’s Royal College of Physicians.
description_for_label: How do you cage a bird? With a thaumatrope, an optical toy that binds a disc to lengths of string. Illustrated on each side of the disc are distinct images that become one when you pull the string and the thaumatrope spins. The first known thaumatrope was invented by John Ayrton Paris in 1824, when he used it to demonstrate his theory of ‘persistence of vision’ to London’s Royal College of Physicians.
